titleStmt.title: An Epistle to a Lady wo desird ye Author

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: After venting all my Spight, del ?EvryÂ·Tell me wt have I to write?
Evry Error I coud find
Thro ye mazes of yr mind,
Has my busy Muse employd
Till ye Company was cloyd.
Are you positive & fretfull,
Heedless Ign'rant & Forgetfull.
Those & twenty Follies more
I have often told before.
Harken wt my Lady says!
Have I nothing yn to praise?
Ill it fits you to be witty
Where a Fault shoud move yr Pity;
If you think me too conceited,
Or to Passion quickly heated,
If my wand'ring head be less
Set on reading yn on dress,
If I always seem too dull t'ye
I can solve ye difficulty.
You woud teach me to be wise
Truth & Honour how to prize,
How to shine in Conversation,
And wth Credit fill my Station,
How to relish Notions high,
How to Live, & how to die;
But it was decreed by Fate,
Mr Dean, you came too late;
Well I know you can discern,
I am now too old to Learn;
Foll overoolies from my Youth instilld
Have my Soul entirely filld,
In my Head & Heart yey Center,
Nor will let yr lessons enter;
Bred a Fondling & an Heiress
Dress'd like any Lady May'ress;
Cockerd by ye Servts round,
Was too good to touch ye ground,
Thought ye Life of evry Lady
Shoud be one continued Play day,
Balls & Masquerades & Shews
Visits, Plays & Powderd Beauxso;
Thus you have my case at large,
And may now perform yr Charge;
Those Materials I have furnishd,
When by you refind & burnishd
Must, that all ye World may know em,
Be reducd into a Poem.
But I beg suspend a while
That same Paultry, burlesque Style;
Drop for once yr Constant Rule
Turning all to Ridicule,
Teaching others how to Ape ye
Courts nor Parliamt can scape ye.
Treat ye Public & yr Friends
Both alike while neither mends.
Sing my Praise in Strain sublime,
Treat me not wth Dogg'rel Rhime.
Tis but just you shoud produce
Wth each Fault each Faults excuse;
Not to Publish ev'ry Triffle
And my few Perfections stiffle,
Wth some gifts at least endow me
Wch my very Foes allow me.
Am I spightfull, proud, unjust?
Did I ever break my trust?
Wch of all our Modern Dames
Censures less or less defames?
In good Manners am I faulty?
Can you call me Rude or Haughty?
Did I e'er my Mite wthhold
From ye Impotent & old?
Wn did ever I omit
Due regard for Men of Wit?
When have I esteem expressd
For a Coxcomb gayly dressd?
Do I like ye Female Tribe
Think it Wit to fleer & Gibe?
Wo wth less designing ends
Kindlier entertains her Friends?
Think not Cards my chief Diversion,
Tis a Wrong unjust Aspersion;
Never knew I any Good in 'em
But to doze my Head like Lodanum.
We by Play as Men by drinking
Pass our Night to drive out thinking.
From my Ailments give me Leisure,
I shall read & think wth Pleasure;
Conversation learn to relish
And my Mind wth Books embellish.
Now methinks I hear you cry,
Mr Dean, you must reply.Madam I allow tis true
All these Praises are yr due;
You like some acute Philosopher
Evry Fault have drawn a Gloss over;
Placing in ye strongest Light
All yr Virtues to my Sight.
Tho you lead a blameless Life,
Are an humble prudent Wife;
Answer all Domestic Ends,
Wt is this to us your Friends?
Tho' yr Children by a Nod
Stand in awe wthout a Rod;
Tho' by your obliging sway
Servants love you & obey;
Tho' you treat us wth a Smile,
Clear yr looks & smooth yr Stile;
Load our Plates from ev'ry dish,
This is not ye thing we wish;
Col'nel ââmay be yr debtor
We expect Employmt better.You must learn if you wd gain us,
Wth good Sense to entertain us.
Scholars, when good sense describing,
Call it Tasting & Imbibing;
Metaphoric Meat & drink
Is to understand & think;
We must carve for others thus,
And let others carve for us:
To discourse & to attend
Is to help yrself & Friend.
Conversation is but carving,
Carve for us, yrself is starving;
Give no more to ev'ry Guest,
Than he's able to digest;
Give him always of ye Prime
And but little at a Time;
Carve to all but just enough,
Let em neither starve nor Stuff;
And that you may have yr due
Let yr Neighbour carve for you.To conclude this long Essay,
Pardon if I disobey,
Nor against my Nat'ral Ve overStrain
Treat you wth Heroic Strain.
I, as all ye Parish knows,
Hardly can be grave in Prose;
Still to las overugh, & las overughing smile,
Ill befits a lofty Stile.
From ye Planet of my Birth
I encounter Vice wth Mirth:
Wicked Ministers of state
I can easier scorn than hate:
And I find it answers right,
Scorn torments em more yn Spight.
All ye Vices of ye Court
Do but serve to make me Sport.Shoud a Monkey wear a Crown,
Must I tremble at his Frown?
Coud I not thro all his Ermine
Spy the strutting, chatt'ring Vermine?
Safely write a Smart Lampoon
To expose ye brisk Baboon?
When my Muse officious ventures
On the Nations representers,
Teaching by wt Golden Rules
Into Knaves yey turn their Fools;
How ye Helm is ruld by Wââââle
At whose Oars like Slaves yey all pull.
Let ye Vessel split on Shelves,
Wth ye Freight enrich ymselves;
Safe wthin my little wherry
All yeir Madness makes me merry.
Like ye Watermen of Thames,
I row by & call ym Names;
Like ye ever-laughing Sage
In a Iest I spend my Rage;
Tho' it must be understood
I woud hang ym if I coud.
If I can but fill my Nitch
I attempt no higher Pitch;
Leave to Danvers & his Mate
Maxims wise to Rule ye State.
Poult'ney deep, accomplishd St Iohns
Scourge ye Villains wth a Vengeance;
Let me, tho' the Smell be noisome,
Strip their Bums, let Caleb hoise 'em,
Then apply Alecto's Whip
Till yey wriggle, howl & skip.Devil's in you, Mr Dean,
Wt can all ys Passion mean?
Mention Courts! youll ne'er be quiet,
On Corruptions running riot.End as it befits yr Station,
Come to use & Application;
Not wth Senates keep a Fuss:I submit & answer thus.
All ye Machinations brewing
To compleat ye Public Ruin
Never once coud have the Power
To affect me half an hour.
If I laugh at Whig & Tory
I conclude a Fortiori
All yr Eloquence will scarce
Drive me from my Fav'rite Farce.
This I must insist on (for as
It is well observd by Horace)
Ridicule has greater Power
To reform ye World yn Sou overwr.
Horses thus, let Iockeys judge else,
Switches better guide yn Cudgels.
Basting heavy, dry, obtuse,
Only Dullness can Produce,
While a little gentle Ierking
Sets ye Spirits all a working.
Thus I find it by Experiment
Scolding moves you less yn Merriment.
I may storm & rage in vain,
It but stupifies yr Brain;
But wth Raillery to nettle,
Sets yr Thoughts upon yeir Mettle;
Gives Imagination scope,
Never lets yr mind elope,
Drives out Brangling & Contention,
Brings in reason, & Invention,
For yr sake as well as mine,
I the lofty Stile decline,
I shoud make a Figure scurvy
And yr head turn topsy-turvy
I (wo love to have a Fling
Both at Senate-house & KingÂ·ââ
That yey might some better way tread
To avoid ye Public Hatred)
Thought no Method more commodious
Than to shew yeir Vices odious,
WchÌ£ I chose to make appear
Not by Anger but a sneer,
As my Method of Reforming
Is by Laughing not by Storming;
For my Friends have often thought
Tenderness my greatest Fault.
Woud you have me change my Stile
On yrFaul overThoughts no longer smile,
But to patch up all our Quarrels
Quote you Texts from Plutarchs Morals,
Or from Solomons Produce
Maxims teaching Wisdom's Use,
If I treat you like a Cââd Hââd
You have cheap enough compounded,
Can you Put in higher claims,
Yn ye owners of St Iames?
You are not so great a Grievance
As ye Hirelings of St StÂ·ââÂ·ââs,
You are of a lower Class
Yn my Friend Sr RââBrass.
None of these have mercy found
I have laughd & lashd ym round,
Have you seen a Rocket fly
You wd say it piercd ye Sky,
It but reachd ye middle Air
Bursting into Pieces there,
Thousand Sparkles falling down
Light on many a Coxcombs Crown;
See What Mirth ye Sport creates,
Singes hair but breakes no Pates.
Thus shoud I attempt to climb,
Treat you in a Stile Sublime,
Such a Rocket is my Muse,
Shoud I lofty Numbers chuse,
E'er I reach Parnassus' top
I shoud burst & bursting drop;
All my Fire wd fall in Scraps.
Give yr Head some gentle raps,
Only make it smart a while;
Then cd I forbear to Smile
Wn I found ye tingling Pain
Entring warm yr frigid Brain,
Make you able upon Sight
To decide of wrong & right;
Talk wth Sense wt e'er you please on
Learn to relish Truth & ReasonThus we both sd gain our Prize,
I to laugh & you grow wise.629-310A
